Name: PUBLISHED - ERB_semiotics-is-everything-a-language
Description: Rulebook generated from Airtable base 'PUBLISHED - ERB_semiotics-is-everything-a-language'.

schema.name: Name
schema.Description: Name of the language candidate being classified.

schema.name: IsLanguage
schema.Description: The test answer that is intended to match the Family Feud answer to be "correct".

schema.name: HasGrammar
schema.Description: Does this candidate have a Grammar?  Generally follows candidates that have syntax also have grammar.

schema.name: HasSyntax
schema.Description: Does this language candidate have syntax and/or grammar?

schema.name: CanBeHeld
schema.Description: Is this candidate physical/material.  I.e. could it at least theoretically "be held"?

schema.name: Question
schema.Description: Question that 100 random people could be asked, family feud style.

schema.name: PredictedAnswer
schema.Description: The predicted answer as the top most popular answer among those in the family feud polling pool.

schema.name: PredictionPredicates
schema.formula: =IF({{HasSyntax}}, "Has Syntax", "No Syntax") & " & " & IF({{IsParsed}}, "Requires Parsing", "No Parsing Neede") & " & " & IF({{IsDescriptionOf}}, "Describes the thing", "Is the Thing") & " & " & IF({{HasLinearDecodingPressure}}, "Has Linear Decoding Pressure", "No Decoding Pressure") & " & " & IF({{ResolvesToAnAST}}, "Resolves to AST", "No AST") & ", " & IF({{IsStableOntologyReference}}, "Is Stable Ontology", "Not 'Ontology'") & " AND " & IF({{CanBeHeld}}, "Can Be Held", "Can't Be Held") & ", " &IF({{HasIdentity}}, "Has Identity", "Has no Identity")

schema.name: PredictionFail
schema.Description: If the family feud answer does not match the chosen language candidates status then this explains what did not match. t also flags (in english) mismatch where a candidate is marked as BOTH open AND closed world which does not make sense.
schema.formula:
=IF(NOT({{PredictedAnswer}} = {{IsLanguage}}),
  {{Name}} & " " & IF({{PredictedAnswer}}, "Is", "Isn't") & " a Family Feud Language, but " & 
  IF({{IsLanguage}}, "Is", "Is Not") & " marked as a 'Language Candidate.'", "") & IF({{IsOpenClosedWorldConflicted}}, " - Open World vs. Closed World Conflict.", "")

schema.name: Category
schema.Description: The general high level category of the candidate.

schema.name: HasIdentity
schema.Description: Could this thing be assigned a guid, unique in the universe that would identify it globally?  Like a drivers license or social security number for a person.

schema.name: IsParsed
schema.Description: Is the knowledge/information encoded in a form that requires parsing before meaning can be extracted?

schema.name: ResolvesToAnAST
schema.Description: Is the knowledge/information encoded in a form that requires parsing before meaning can be extracted?

data.Name: English

data.Name: NEIAL-001
data.Statement: To avoid the slogan 'Everything is a language', treat 'language' as a typed construct defined by testable properties (syntax, parsing, linear decoding pressure, and descriptor-role).
data.Notes: This keeps 'can be interpreted' separate from 'is a language system'.

data.Name: NEIAL-002
data.Statement: Use the repo predicates: HasSyntax, RequiresParsing, HasLinearDecodingPressure, StableOntologyReference (spelled IsOngologyDescriptor in the dataset), plus auxiliary checks like CanBeHeld and HasIdentity.
data.Formalization: Predicates: Syntax(x), Parse(x), SerializeMeaning(x), OntDesc(x), Tangible(x)
data.Notes: We preserve the dataset's field name even when misspelled to match the generated schema.

data.Name: NEIAL-003
data.Statement: Operational definition: an item x counts as a Language if it has syntax, requires parsing, serializes meaning, and functions as an ontology/descriptor system.
data.Notes: This is a deliberately 'strong' definition: it matches formal languages and many natural language representations.

data.Name: NEIAL-004
data.Statement: There exists at least one clear witness that satisfies the operational definition: English.
data.EvidenceFromRulebook: HasSyntax=True; RequiresParsing=True; HasLinearDecodingPressure=True; IsOngologyDescriptor=True; CanBeHeld=False; HasIdentity=False; DistanceFromConcept=2; Category=Natural Language
data.Notes: If any predicate is false in your current dataset for this witness, adjust the candidate record or relax the definition.

data.Name: NEIAL-005
data.Statement: There exists at least one clear witness that satisfies the operational definition: Python.
data.EvidenceFromRulebook: HasSyntax=True; RequiresParsing=True; HasLinearDecodingPressure=True; IsOngologyDescriptor=True; CanBeHeld=False; HasIdentity=False; DistanceFromConcept=2; Category=Formal Language
data.Notes: If any predicate is false in your current dataset for this witness, adjust the candidate record or relax the definition.

data.Name: NEIAL-006
data.Statement: Therefore, 'language' can be formalized as a computable classification boundary over explicit predicates.
data.Notes: This is the concession: language is formalizable (at least operationally).

data.Name: NEIAL-007
data.Statement: If Language(x) is defined by necessary conditions, then any x that fails at least one condition is not a language.
data.Notes: This is the standard move: a definition implies exclusions.

data.Name: NEIAL-008
data.Statement: Counterexample: a chair can be interpreted as a sign (status, design, function), but it does not constitute a language system under the operational definition.
data.Notes: This separates semiotic availability (can signify) from linguistic structure (has syntax/parsing/serialized meaning).

data.Name: NEIAL-009
data.Statement: Non-language example: A Thunderstorm can be meaningful, but meaning here is not generated by an explicit syntax+parsing+serialization descriptor system.
data.EvidenceFromRulebook: HasSyntax=False; RequiresParsing=True; HasLinearDecodingPressure=False; IsOngologyDescriptor=False; CanBeHeld=False; HasIdentity=True; DistanceFromConcept=1; Category=Physical event
data.Notes: These are strong candidates for 'sign vehicles' rather than 'languages'.

data.Name: NEIAL-010
data.Statement: Non-language example: A Coffee Mug can be meaningful, but meaning here is not generated by an explicit syntax+parsing+serialization descriptor system.
data.EvidenceFromRulebook: HasSyntax=False; RequiresParsing=False; HasLinearDecodingPressure=False; IsOngologyDescriptor=False; CanBeHeld=True; HasIdentity=True; DistanceFromConcept=1; Category=Physical Object
data.Notes: These are strong candidates for 'sign vehicles' rather than 'languages'.

data.Name: NEIAL-011
data.Statement: Non-language example: The Mona Lisa can be meaningful, but meaning here is not generated by an explicit syntax+parsing+serialization descriptor system.
data.EvidenceFromRulebook: HasSyntax=False; RequiresParsing=False; HasLinearDecodingPressure=False; IsOngologyDescriptor=True; CanBeHeld=True; HasIdentity=True; DistanceFromConcept=1; Category=Physical Object
data.Notes: These are strong candidates for 'sign vehicles' rather than 'languages'.

data.Name: NEIAL-012
data.Statement: Fuzzy case: A Running App often contains embedded languages (code, UI grammars), but as an executing/interactive process it behaves like a dynamic system rather than a static serialized language artifact.
data.Formalization: Borderline(A Running App): may contain ∃y Language(y) but ¬Language(A Running App) under static-serialization criteria
data.Notes: This is where traditional semiotics' 'anything is a sign' doesn’t neatly distinguish: (1) language-as-system vs (2) meaning-making interactive processes.

data.Name: NEIAL-013
data.Statement: Fuzzy case: Running Calculator App often contains embedded languages (code, UI grammars), but as an executing/interactive process it behaves like a dynamic system rather than a static serialized language artifact.
data.Formalization: Borderline(Running Calculator App): may contain ∃y Language(y) but ¬Language(Running Calculator App) under static-serialization criteria
data.EvidenceFromRulebook: HasSyntax=False; RequiresParsing=True; HasLinearDecodingPressure=False; IsOngologyDescriptor=False; CanBeHeld=False; HasIdentity=True; DistanceFromConcept=1; Category=Running Software
data.Notes: This is where traditional semiotics' 'anything is a sign' doesn’t neatly distinguish: (1) language-as-system vs (2) meaning-making interactive processes.

data.Name: NEIAL-014
data.Statement: Fuzzy case: A Game of Fortnite often contains embedded languages (code, UI grammars), but as an executing/interactive process it behaves like a dynamic system rather than a static serialized language artifact.
data.Formalization: Borderline(A Game of Fortnite): may contain ∃y Language(y) but ¬Language(A Game of Fortnite) under static-serialization criteria
data.EvidenceFromRulebook: HasSyntax=False; RequiresParsing=True; HasLinearDecodingPressure=False; IsOngologyDescriptor=False; CanBeHeld=False; HasIdentity=True; DistanceFromConcept=1; Category=Running Software
data.Notes: This is where traditional semiotics' 'anything is a sign' doesn’t neatly distinguish: (1) language-as-system vs (2) meaning-making interactive processes.

data.Name: NEIAL-015
data.Statement: Refinement: distinguish LanguageSystem (syntax/parsing/serialization descriptor) from SemioticProcess (interactive/dynamic meaning production) and from SignVehicle (object/phenomenon used as a sign).
data.Notes: This gives you a place to put running apps and games without forcing 'language' to swallow everything.

data.Name: NEIAL-016
data.Statement: Given a formalizable definition of language, not everything is a language; some things are better treated as sign vehicles or semiotic processes, with running applications as a key fuzzy region that benefits from explicit modeling.
data.Notes: This is the repo's thesis in one line.

data.Name: 01b-customize-schema.sql
data.Title: Customize Schema
data.SQLCode:
-- ============================================================================
-- CUSTOMIZE SCHEMA - User-defined tables and schema modifications
-- ============================================================================
-- This file is for YOUR custom schema changes that should persist across
-- regeneration of the base ERB files.
--
-- USE THIS FILE FOR:
--   - Additional tables not defined in the rulebook
--   - Extra columns on existing tables (ALTER TABLE)
--   - Custom indexes for performance tuning
--   - Custom constraints or triggers
--
-- IMPORTANT:
--   - This file runs AFTER 01-drop-and-create-tables.sql
--   - The base tables already exist when this runs
--   - This file will NOT be overwritten by ERB regeneration
--
-- ============================================================================

-- Your custom schema changes go here:

data.Name: 02b-customize-functions.sql
data.Title: Customize Functions
data.SQLCode:
-- Prediction Fail: Returns TRUE when predicted_answer doesn't match is_language
DROP FUNCTION calc_language_candidates_question;

CREATE OR REPLACE FUNCTION public.calc_language_candidates_question(p_language_candidate_id text)
 RETURNS text
 LANGUAGE plpgsql
 STABLE SECURITY DEFINER
AS $function$
BEGIN
  RETURN ('Is ' || (SELECT NULLIF(name, '''') FROM language_candidates WHERE language_candidate_id = p_language_candidate_id) || ' a language?')::text;
END;
$function$

_meta._CMCC_Summary: Airtable export with schema-first type mapping: Schemas, Data, Relationships (FK links), Lookups (INDEX/MATCH), Aggregations (SUMIFS/COUNTIFS/Rollups), and Calculated fields (formulas) in Excel dialect. Field types are determined from Airtable's schema metadata FIRST (no coercion), with intelligent fallback to formula/data analysis only when schema is unavailable.

_conversion_metadata.field_type_mapping: checkbox→boolean, number→number/integer, multipleRecordLinks→relationship, multipleLookupValues→lookup, rollup→aggregation, count→aggregation, formula→calculated

type_inference.priority: airtable_metadata (NO COERCION) → formula_analysis → reference_resolution → data_analysis (fallback only)
type_inference.airtable_type_mapping: checkbox→boolean, singleLineText→string, multilineText→string, number→number/integer, datetime→datetime, singleSelect→string, email→string, url→string, phoneNumber→string
type_inference.data_coercion_hierarchy: Only used as fallback when Airtable schema unavailable: datetime → number → integer → boolean → base64 → json → string
